channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Centuries-old remains found in a well may be man from Norse saga
item.description: An old Norse story tells of a king's man being tossed down a well in 1197. An archeologist teamed up with an evolutionary genomicist to study DNA of a skeleton found in that well.
item.content:encoded:
An old Norse story tells of a king's man being tossed down a well in 1197. An archeologist teamed up with an evolutionary genomicist to study DNA of a skeleton found in that well.

(Image credit: Riksantikvaren (The Norwegian Directorate for Cultural Heritage))
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Opinion: Nature dazzles in autumn
item.description: NPR's Scott Simon is dazzled by the turn of the seasons, especially the color of the leaves.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's Scott Simon is dazzled by the turn of the seasons, especially the color of the leaves.

(Image credit: Caroline Simon)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Freeman hits 1st walk-off slam in World Series history as Dodgers top Yankees in Game 1
item.description: Freddie Freeman hit the first game-ending grand slam in World Series history in the 10th inning to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 6-3 victory over the New York Yankees in a drama-filled opener.
item.content:encoded:
Freddie Freeman hit the first game-ending grand slam in World Series history in the 10th inning to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 6-3 victory over the New York Yankees in a drama-filled opener.

(Image credit: Ashley Landis)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Remembering Dr. Richard Cash: How a 'simple' intervention helped save millions of lives
item.description: In the late 1960s, he went to Dhaka to work on cholera. There he became involved in the development of oral rehydration therapy — hailed as one of the most significant medical advances of the century.
item.content:encoded:
In the late 1960s, he went to Dhaka to work on cholera. There he became involved in the development of oral rehydration therapy — hailed as one of the most significant medical advances of the century.

(Image credit: Kent Dayton)
item.dc:creator: Joanne Silberner

item.title: Many state abortion bans include exceptions for rape. How often are they granted?
item.description: Since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade in 2022, one study estimates there’s been nearly 65,000 pregnancies from rape in states that ban abortion.
item.content:encoded:
Since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade in 2022, one study estimates there’s been nearly 65,000 pregnancies from rape in states that ban abortion.

(Image credit: Geoff Stellfox for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: The Jan. 6 riot included Marines. The military is wrestling with the consequences
item.description: A Marine and his buddies joined the mob that entered the Capitol on Jan. 6. They were not the only Marines there. NPR asked the Corps' top officer a question: Do the Marines have an extremism problem?
item.content:encoded:
A Marine and his buddies joined the mob that entered the Capitol on Jan. 6. They were not the only Marines there. NPR asked the Corps' top officer a question: Do the Marines have an extremism problem?

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura/Los Angeles Times via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: How civil society groups are quietly working to prevent election-related violence
item.description: Few political violence researchers believe there will be a repeat of the Jan. 6th attack. Instead, many warn that election-related violence is more likely to happen in local communities.
item.content:encoded:
Few political violence researchers believe there will be a repeat of the Jan. 6th attack. Instead, many warn that election-related violence is more likely to happen in local communities.

(Image credit: Samuel Corum)
item.dc:creator: Odette Yousef

item.title: Sun, sea and sirens: A summer in Odesa
item.description: This summer, despite the ongoing conflict, photographer Simona Supino captured an Odesa, Ukraine's coastal jewel, determined to hold onto its vibrancy and sense of normalcy.
item.content:encoded:
This summer, despite the ongoing conflict, photographer Simona Supino captured an Odesa, Ukraine's coastal jewel, determined to hold onto its vibrancy and sense of normalcy.

(Image credit: Simona Supino)
item.dc:creator: Simona Supino

item.title: GOP lawsuits about an obscure immigration database may set up election challenges
item.description: Florida, Texas and Ohio have filed last-minute lawsuits against the Biden administration demanding data about the citizenship of voters on their state rolls. One expert calls these "zombie" lawsuits.
item.content:encoded:
Florida, Texas and Ohio have filed last-minute lawsuits against the Biden administration demanding data about the citizenship of voters on their state rolls. One expert calls these "zombie" lawsuits.

(Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: Don't get duped into buying fake products online. Look out for these 4 red flags
item.description: Counterfeit products, especially medicines and safety gear, can be dangerous. Here's how to spot them on e-commerce platforms like Amazon.
item.content:encoded:
Counterfeit products, especially medicines and safety gear, can be dangerous. Here's how to spot them on e-commerce platforms like Amazon.

(Image credit: Kirill Greshnov)
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra
